statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: CS Northridge 81, USC 76 (OT)
article.story: LOS ANGELES (AP) -- Southern California should have known Cal State Northridge was going to be trouble. Sure, the Matadors had lost their four previous meetings with the Trojans. But each time it was by fewer and fewer points, including two years ago when they fell six points short of a victory. It happened Sunday, when Mike Efevberha scored 20 points and Northridge won 81-76 in overtime, spoiling Tim Floyd's debut as coach of the Trojans. "I don't know how it ended up in overtime because we played well enough to win it in regulation," Northridge coach Bobby Braswell said. "I could see they were devastated to be in overtime, especially when Mike missed that free throw." With Northridge clinging to a 70-68 lead, Efevberha missed and freshman RouSean Cromwell dunked with eight-tenths of a second left to force overtime tied at 70. "I felt terrible because I knew if I had knocked that one down, we would've won," said Efevberha, who was playing his first college game in more than a year after transferring from UC Irvine. "It felt great to come in here on the road and beat a great Pac-10 team." Floyd is back in college basketball after a seven-year absence, during which he had an unsuccessful NBA stint with Chicago and New Orleans. Asked how he felt, Floyd said, "Not very good right now, but it's great to be back in the college game. I'm grateful to have this job." The Matadors' win was the second by a Big West team over the Pac-10 in as many days, with UC Irvine stunning No. 13 Stanford 79-63 Saturday. Nick Young led USC with 18 points before fouling out in regulation. Cromwell added 17 points and 12 rebounds -- the most by a freshman since Sam Clancy had 14 on Feb. 6, 1999. "It showed out there, we didn't give up," Young said. "Last year, there wouldn't have been any positive energy out there." Jonathan Heard scored Northridge's first five points in overtime, and finished with 15. The Matadors (1-0) had 21 turnovers. In overtime, Keith Everage scored with one second left on the shot clock to keep the Matadors ahead 77-74. Gabe Pruitt missed two jumpers in the final minute for the Trojans, who opened their last season in the aging Sports Arena before moving to a new on-campus building. "Both looks Gabe had were terrific, they just didn't go down," Floyd said. The Trojans took 27 3-pointers, making just four. Pruitt went 0-for-10 from long-range. "I hope it was an off-night for Gabe," Floyd said. In regulation, Sead Odzic hit a 3-pointer from the left side to get USC within one with 25 seconds left. Northridge's Bakari Altheimer got fouled and made one of two for a 70-68 lead. Pruitt was called for traveling on a drive with 10 seconds to go before Cromwell's tying dunk. "This team has a lot of heart," Cromwell said. "That's a major improvement over last year." Young's 3-pointer gave USC its largest lead, 27-22, in the first half. The Matadors then outscored USC 19-5 to end the half ahead 42-32. The Trojans never led in the second half, when they had four freshmen on the floor at times.
